To Create a Landed Cost Document To allocate landed costs among items of either purchase receipts or transfer receipts, you create a landed cost document on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO303000|PO303000]) Landed Costs (PO303000) form. To Create a Purchase Order Open the ([~/?ScreenId=PO303000|PO303000]) Landed Costs (PO303000) form. Select the landed cost vendor in the Vendor box. Check the location of the vendor, and change it if needed. Optional: In the Currency box, heck the currency and the currency exchange rate; change these, if needed. Check the date of the purchase order, and change it if needed. Optional: In the Vendor Ref. box, specify the reference number of the vendor's original document. (This value may be required, based on your organization's settings.) Optional: Select the Create Bill box, if you want the system to generate the Accounts Payable bill automatically on release of the landed cost document. Specify a short description of the landed cost document. To add all lines of documents to which the landed costs should be allocated, on the table toolbar of the Document Details tab, click Add PO Receipt , and do the following in the Add Receipt dialog box, which opens: In the Type box, select Receipt to display purchase receipts in the table, or Transfer Receipt to display transfer receipts. Select the unlabeled check boxes in the rows with the receipts whose lines should be added. Click Add & Close to add the lines of the receipts and close the dialog box. To add the particular lines of either purchase receipts or transfer receipts to which the landed costs should be allocated, on the table toolbar of the Document Details tab, click Add PO Receipt Line , and do the following in the Add Receipt Line dialog box, which opens: In the Type box, if it is available, select Receipt to display purchase receipts in the table, or Transfer Receipt to display transfer receipts. Select the unlabeled check boxes in the rows with the receipt lines to be added. Click Add & Close to add the selected receipt lines and close the dialog box. On the Document Details tab, review the information in the added lines, and make changes to weight and volume in lines, if needed. On the Landed Costs tab, for each landed cost amount that you want to allocate to the added receipt lines, click Add Row on the table toolbar, and do the following: In the Branch column, ensure that the system has specified the correct branch. In the Landed Cost Code column, select the landed cost code. In the Amount column, specify the landed cost amount to be allocated. Optional: In the Tax Category box, change the appropriate tax category if the landed cost amounts are subject to taxes. Optional: In the Inventory ID box, select a particular item if the landed cost amount should be allocated to only lines with this particular item ID. Click Save on the form toolbar. Clear the Hold check box in the Summary area. Click Save on the form toolbar.

To Add Landed Costs to a Bill To add line or lines of a landed cost document to an Accounts Payable bill to a landed cost vendor, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form. To Add a Landed Cost Line to Bill Open the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form. In the Type box, select Bill , and select the needed bill by its reference number. On the table toolbar of the Document Details tab, click Add LC . In the Add LC dialog box, which opens, do the following: Optional: Filter the lines in the table by selecting any of the following: the particular landed cost document in the LC Nbr. box, the particular receipt in the Receipt Nbr. box, or the particular landed cost code in the LC Code box. In the table, select the unlabeled check boxes in the line or lines with the landed costs to be added to the bill. Click Add & Close to close the dialog box and add the selected lines. On the Document Details tab, review the added lines, and correct their Ext. Cost , if needed. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes. Notes About the Procedure The notes in this section describe the nuances of the UI elements available on the form, such as when an element is required and when it is not, and when the system fills in settings by default. This section can include other notes. Note the following about adding landed costs to a bill: The Add LC dialog box shows the lines of released landed cost documents for which the AP bill wasn't created on release. If you correct the landed cost amount in the bill, the occurred difference between the estimated amount in the landed cost document and corrected amount billed to landed cost vendor is posted to the Landed Cost Variance account. For details, see Adjusting the Landed Cost Variance.

To Link a Bill Line to Landed Cost Document To link a particular line of an existing Accounts Payable bill to a line of landed cost document, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form. To Link an Accounts Payable Bill to Landed Cost Document Open the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form. In the Type box, select Bill , and select the needed bill by its reference number. On the table toolbar of the Document Details tab, click a line with an empty inventory ID to which a landed cost should be linked, and click Link Line on the table toolbar. In the Link Line dialog box, which opens with the Landed Cost mode selected, select the unlabeled check box next to the landed cost line to be linked. Click Add & Close to close the dialog box and link the selected line. Optional: Correct the Ext. Cost of the bill line, if needed. Click Save to save your changes. Notes About the Procedure The notes in this section describe the nuances of the UI elements available on the form, such as when an element is required and when it is not, and when the system fills in settings by default. This section can include other notes. Note the following about adding landed costs to a bill: You can link a landed costs line to a line with empty Inventory ID only. Once you have linked a landed cost line, the description of a bill line changes to the description of the linked landed cost. Each bill line can be linked to only one landed cost line. The Link Line dialog box shows the lines of released landed cost documents for which the Accounts Payable bill wasn't created on release. If the amount in the bill line differs from the amount in the landed cost line that you linked, the occurred difference is posted to the Landed Cost Variance account. For details, see Adjusting the Landed Cost Variance.

Allocati ng Purchase Price Variance The purchase price variance (PPV) amount is the difference between an item's actual unit cost on a purchase receipt (calculated as the item extended cost divided by its quantity) and its actual unit cost on a bill (calculated as the extended cost divided by the quantity on the bill) multiplied by the quantity of the item on the bill. In Acumatica ERP, on purchase orders, purchase receipts, inventory receipts, and bills, the purchase prices of items are referred to as costs . The difference may occur due to various reasons, such as exchange rate fluctuations or unplanned changes in the vendor price or delivery costs. Different businesses may use different approaches when accounting for the purchase price variance amounts. The topic describes the options available in Acumatica ERP for allocation of the purchase price variance amounts for stock items. PPV Calculation Generally, the actual vendor prices and discounts may change frequently, and when you enter a purchase receipt on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO302000|PO302000]) Purchase Receipts (PO302000) form and specify an item by its inventory ID, the exact vendor price and applicable discounts are not known. Even if the unit cost appears automatically in the Unit Cost column, you can manually enter only the item quantity and the extended cost (which may include the vendor's current promotional price and discount for the specified quantity not yet configured in the system); the extended cost will not be recalculated based on the unit cost. For the PPV calculation, the system will use the actual unit cost (calculated as the extended amount per unit), not the unit cost that is available in the system and was inserted automatically. When you enter a related bill by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form, you know the prices and any additional costs, and you can reflect them on the bill. On release of a bill that is linked to the purchase receipt, the system calculates the purchase price variance amount for each line item as follows: Calculates the unit's actual cost on the purchase receipt as the extended cost on the purchase receipt divided by the quantity Calculates the unit's actual cost on the bill as the extended cost on the bill divided by the quantity on the bill Subtracts the unit's actual cost on the bill from the unit's actual cost on the receipt Multiplies the difference by the quantity on the bill For example, the following documents (a purchase receipt and the AP bill linked to the receipt) were entered into the system. Receipt Details Item Quantity Extended Cost New Item1 20 4500 New Item2 30 9000 Bill Details Item Quantity Extended Cost New Item1 10 2000 New Item2 30 9900 The PPV amounts are calculated as follows: PPV Calculation Item Quantity PPV New Item1 10 250 New Item2 30 -900 The ways the calculated PPV amounts can be allocated depend on the item valuation method and the selected allocation mode and are described in the following sections. PPV Allocation for Exchange Rate Changes By default, in a purchase receipt, the system inserts the currency rate that is current on the purchase receipt date. If needed, you can override the default currency rate if all of the following are true: The Multi-Currency Accounting feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. The Allow Changing Currency Rate on Receipt check box is selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO101000|PO101000]) Purchase Orders Preferences (PO101000) form. The Enable Rate Override check box is selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=AP303000|AP303000]) Vendors (AP303000) form for the vendor specified in the purchase receipt. The system will use the new exchange rate for calculating the unit cost of the items in the inventory receipt that it creates on release of the current purchase receipt. On release of an AP bill that is linked to this purchase receipt, the system calculates the purchase price variance amount for each line item as follows: Calculates the unit's actual cost on the purchase receipt based on the exchange rate of the purchase receipt Calculates the unit's actual cost on the bill based on the exchange rate of the bill Subtracts the unit's actual cost on the bill from the unit's actual cost on the receipt Multiplies the difference by the quantity on the bill PPV Allocation for Items with Standard Costs For stock items with Standard assigned as the cost valuation method on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, any PPV amounts are allocated to the Purchase Price Variance account defined by the posting class of the item. For more information, see the Standard Cost Valuation Method section of the Item Costs and Valuation Methods topic. PPV Allocation Modes for Items with Other Valuation Methods In Acumatica ERP, you can select how you want to process the purchase price variance amounts for stock items with the following valuation methods: Average , FIFO , or Specific . On the ([~/?ScreenId=PO101000|PO101000]) Purchase Orders Preferences (PO101000) form, you can select one of the following modes of PPV allocation: Inventory Account : To record the variance to the inventory accounts to update the item costs. If you select this mode, you also need to select the reason code (in the adjacent box) that will provide the expense accounts and subaccounts used for the allocation of the PPV amounts. Purchase Price Variance Account : To record any variance amounts to the purchase price variance accounts to be further processed as additional expenses. The modes of PPV allocation are discussed in detail in the sections below. The Inventory Account Mode of PPV Allocation If the Inventory Account mode is selected as the mode of PPV allocation, on release of a bill, an inventory adjustment for the PPV amounts is generated automatically. You can view the reference number of the adjustment in the PPV Ref. Nbr. column on the Document Details tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments form. Consider a few scenarios that may occur with a received stock item (with no lot or serial numbers) when the bill is released: If no units of the item have been issued from a warehouse since the item was received, this adjustment debits the inventory account of the item for the positive variance amount and credits the PO Accrual account (or credits the inventory account for the negative amount and debits the PO Accrual account for the same amount). See Purchase Price Variance Allocation: Example 1. If all the units of the item have been issued from a warehouse before the bill has been created and an adjustment has been generated, this adjustment debits the variance amount to the expense account associated with the reason code. If some (but not all) of the units of the item have been issued from the warehouse, the adjustment distributes the variance amount proportionally between the quantity of units issued and the quantity of units still in the warehouse, and allocates the respective amounts to the expense account (associated with the reason code) and to the inventory account. For details, see Purchase Price Variance Allocation: Example 2. If multiple bills are created for partial quantities of items from a receipt and certain quantities of the items (from that receipt) have been issued from the warehouse, the PPV amounts on each adjustment generated for a partial bill are allocated between the inventory accounts and the expense accounts in the same proportion in which the original quantities from the receipt are distributed between the quantities issued and the quantities still in stock. If a PPV adjustment would result in negative balance of the inventory account, the adjustment amount is posted to the expense account. If you need to reverse the bill linked to the receipt, you can do this only if the adjustment has been released. On reversal of the bill, no new adjustment is created to revert the original adjustment—the original adjustment remains in the system. If you then create a second bill for the same purchase receipt, the system generates a new adjustment that adjusts the first (original) adjustment. The Purchase Price Variance Account Mode of PPV Allocation If Purchase Price Variance Account is selected as the mode of PPV allocation, on release of a bill, the entire PPV amount is recorded to the Purchase Price Variance account defined by the posting class of the item . row.PlainText: Processing Purchase Requisitions The Purchase Requisitions module, a part of the inventory and order management functionality, provides your organization with ability to create and process requests for goods and services, approve requests, and prevent cost overruns. The Purchase Requisitions module provides configurable, budget-compliant request documents. Also, the module facilitates a bidding process. The purchase requisitions functionality is available only if the Purchase Requisitions feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. If available, this module is integrated with the financial modules, as well as with the Inventory and Purchase Orders modules. This chapter contains information you need to configure and use the purchase requisitions functionality.

row.column: Basic Purchase Requisition Process An organization may want to pursue a clear, cost-efficient purchasing process that prioritizes the purchase of items from the most appropriate vendors at the best possible time and in the right quantities. To facilitate this process, an organization can use purchase requests and requisitions—that is, documents that track the items the organization wants to purchase from vendors. In Acumatica ERP, you can create requests, create purchase requisitions based on these requests, and solicit bids from multiple vendors so that your personnel can select the best bid. To use the requisition functionality, you must have the Purchase Requisitions feature enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. In this topic, you will find information about the basic process of purchase requisitions in Acumatica ERP. Request Classes in Acumatica ERPA request class is an entity in Acumatica ERP that contains the general settings for requests of a particular type. You can create a request class on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ201000|RQ201000]) Request Classes (RQ201000) form and specify the following settings for the class: What the promised lead time is: In the Promised Lead Time (days) box (Summary area), you specify the number of days within which a request of the class should be fulfilled. Whether requests of the class are external or internal: External requests contain items requested by customers of your organization. To indicate that the request class will be used for external requests, you select the Customer Request check box in the Summary area. Internal requests are initiated by employees of your organization and contain items that the employees need in their work. Whether the items from a request of the class can be divided among multiple vendors: If a request contains multiple items, you can order these items from multiple vendors if one vendor cannot fulfill the entire request or if another vendor has lower prices for particular items. You select the Allow Multiple Vendors per Request check box, also in the Summary area, to indicate that the system can suggest multiple vendors to fulfill the request. Which items are available for ordering in requests of this class (optional): You can restrict the list of items that users can add to the request during creation to reduce the probability of mistakenly added items. To do this, you select the Restrict Requests Items to the Specified List check box in the Summary area, and you add the items to the list on the Request Class Item List tab. Whether the request must be validated against the budget: If you control expenses on particular items by using budgets, you can set up budget validation on the GL Accounts tab by selecting Warning or Error in the Budget Validation box (the default setting is None ) and specifying an expense account in the Expense Account box (and the corresponding subaccount, if applicable, in the Expense Sub. box). Purchase Requisition Usage In a simple case of using purchase requests and requisitions, you create one request or multiple requests, and then you create a purchase requisition based on the requests, manually select a vendor, and purchase items from this vendor (see the following diagram). You can use this simplified process, for example, when employees of your organization order low-cost items, such as office supplies. If you already work with a vendor that gives your company the best prices and discounts for these items, you do not need to gather bids from multiple vendors to save on price. Overview of the simplified requisition process If your organization works with multiple vendors that provide you with the same type of items (such as computers), you can request and process vendor bids to select the best offers. For example, if you have received an order for laptops from your employees, you can find a vendor or multiple vendors with the lowest prices to fulfill the order. Depending on the business processes of your organization, you can use budget validation for requests or approvals for requests and requisitions to secure the purchase requisitions process against fraud and unnecessary expenses. For more information, see Extended Purchase Requisition Process. Basic Purchase Requisition Process The basic purchase requisition process includes the following steps (also shown in the diagrams below): Creating a request: You create a request by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests (RQ301000) form. Creating a purchase requisition based on one request or multiple requests: You create a purchase requisition on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ504000|RQ504000]) Create Requisitions (RQ504000) form. Sending proposals to vendors by email (optional): You automatically send requests for proposals to vendors by email by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) form. Selecting a vendor (or multiple vendors) for the purchase: If you manually select a vendor (or multiple vendors for different items) for the requisition, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions form. If you have run automatic bidding, you analyze and correct the automatic bidding results by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding (RQ503000) form. For details on selecting vendors, see Processing and Selection of Bids. Creating all needed purchase orders (and, optionally, all needed sales orders for external requests): You create these orders by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions form. Sending all purchase orders that have been created to the applicable vendors: By using the ([~/?ScreenId=PO301000|PO301000]) Purchase Orders (PO301000) form, you send the created purchase order or orders to the vendor or vendors selected to fulfill the requisition. Receiving items in a warehouse: You create and process the documents related to the items being received in a warehouse by using the ([~/?ScreenId=PO301000|PO301000]) Purchase Orders and ([~/?ScreenId=PO302000|PO302000]) Purchase Receipts (PO302000) forms. Providing items to requesters: For external requests, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=SO301000|SO301000]) Sales Orders (SO301000) and ([~/?ScreenId=SO302000|SO302000]) Shipments (SO302000) forms to create and process the documents for shipping items to customers. For internal requests, you can create and process the documents for issuing items to employees of your organization by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN302000|IN302000]) Issues (IN302000) form. Overview of requisition process with bids (part 1) Overview of requisition process with bids (part 2) Creation of a Purchase Requisition Document After the requests have been created, you create a requisition document. You can include multiple requests in one requisition if the items in these requests will be ordered from the same vendors. For creating a requisition, you can use the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ504000|RQ504000]) Create Requisitions (RQ504000) or ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) form. On the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ504000|RQ504000]) Create Requisitions form, you can create any number of requisitions. While on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions form, you can fully process a requisition (from creation to release). When the system is creating a requisition, it can merge lines with the same items into one line if the item was requested by the same requester (a customer or an employee) and has the same estimated unit cost. If you want the system to merge items in all requisitions, you can select the Merge Lines by Default check box on the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form. Before you create any requisitions on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ504000|RQ504000]) Create Requisitions form, you can select the Merge Lines check box in the Selection area to merge items for created requisitions, or clear the check box to not merge items. If a requisition has already been created, you can merge lines manually on the Document Details tab of the Requisitions form by selecting the Included check box for the lines in the list and clicking Merge Lines on the table toolbar. With manual merging in this way, the system will merge lines even if they have different unit costs and requesters. For external requests, we do not recommend that you merge items requested by different customers, because this may cause sales documents to be linked incorrectly to purchase requisitions. Sending of Requests for Proposals If you have email functionality configured in the system, you can automatically send requests for proposals to vendors by email by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) form. To do this, on the Bidding tab, you select a vendor in the Bidding Vendors table and click Send Request . Alternatively, you can send requests to all vendors at once by clicking Vendor Notifications Send All Requests on the form toolbar. Extended Purchase Requisition Process If your organization takes measures to secure the purchasing process against fraud and unnecessary expenses, in Acumatica ERP, you can configure validation of requests against budget and approval of requests and requisitions as extensions of the basic process. In this topic, you will read about the extended process of purchase requisitions. Advanced Purchase Requisition Process The purchasing process that involves budget validation and approval of requests and requisitions includes the following steps (also shown in the diagrams below): Creating a request: You create a request by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests (RQ301000) form. Validating a request against a budget: You analyze the validation results on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests form and correct the list of items if the request cost exceeds the budget. Approving the request: The employee that is assigned as the request approver approves or rejects the request by using the ([~/?ScreenId=EP503010|EP503010]) Approvals (EP503010) or ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests form. Creating a purchase requisition based on one request or multiple requests: You create a purchase requisition on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ504000|RQ504000]) Create Requisitions (RQ504000) form. Approving the requisition: The assigned requisition approver approves or rejects the requisition by using the ([~/?ScreenId=EP503010|EP503010]) Approvals or ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests form. Sending notifications to vendors: On the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) form, you send a request for proposal to each vendor that may opt to participate in bidding by clicking the vendor on the Bidding tab (in the Bidding Vendors table) and clicking Send Request on the table toolbar. Entering vendor responses: You enter vendor responses into the system by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) Bidding Responses (RQ303000) form. Running automatic bidding: On the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding (RQ503000) form, you run automatic bidding among vendors. Selecting a vendor (or multiple vendors) for the purchase: You use the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions form to manually select a vendor (or multiple vendors for different items) for the requisition. If you have run automatic bidding, you analyze and correct the automatic bidding results by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding form. Creating all needed purchase orders (and, optionally, all needed sales orders for external requests): You create these orders from the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions form. Sending all purchase orders that have been created to the applicable vendors: By using the ([~/?ScreenId=PO301000|PO301000]) Purchase Orders (PO301000) form, you send the created purchase order or orders to the vendor or vendors selected to fulfill the requisition. Receiving items in a warehouse: You create and process the documents related to the items being received in a warehouse by using the ([~/?ScreenId=PO301000|PO301000]) Purchase Orders and ([~/?ScreenId=PO302000|PO302000]) Purchase Receipts (PO302000) forms. Providing items to requesters: For external requests, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=SO301000|SO301000]) Sales Orders (SO301000) and ([~/?ScreenId=SO302000|SO302000]) Shipments (SO302000) forms to create and process the documents for shipping items to customers. For internal requests, you create and process the documents for issuing items to employees of your organization by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN302000|IN302000]) Issues (IN302000) form. Process of purchase requisitions with budget validation and approval (part 1) Process of purchase requisitions with budget validation and approval (part 2) Request and Requisition Approvals In the system, you can create approval maps so that requests that meet particular criteria are submitted for approval to the appropriate employees. For example, if the total cost of the items in a request exceeds a particular amount, the request must be approved by the head of the department whose employee requested the items. You can configure the system so that particular requisitions or all requisitions require approval. For example, approval can be set up so that all requisitions that contain computer equipment that costs more than a particular amount must be approved by the IT department before purchasing can take place. Before you turn on the approval of requests and requisitions, you should make sure that the needed approval maps and notification templates (if needed) have been configured. The approval map defines the employees designated for approving documents and the conditions that the documents must meet (if applicable) to be assigned for approval; the template of the notification email will be used by the system for notifying approvers about the documents pending their approval. You then enable the approval of purchase requests or requisitions on the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form by selecting the appropriate Require Approval check box (in the Request Settings or Requisition Settings section). Then on the Approval tab of this form, for each document type (request or requisition), you specify the approval map and, optionally, the template of the notification email. For the step-by-step instruction, see To Set Up Approval of Requests and Requisitions. With approvals turned on, when a purchase request or requisition that is subject to approval has been created, taken off hold, and saved, the document is assigned the Pending Approval status. The responsible approver receives an email notification (if an email notification template has been specified for this type of document) about the document pending approval. On the ([~/?ScreenId=EP503010|EP503010]) Approvals (EP503010) form, an approver can review the list of documents pending approval, and can select one record or multiple records in the list and approve or reject all selected records. To be able to approve requests and requisitions, an approver must have access to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests (RQ301000) and ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) forms accordingly. If the document is approved, the system assigns it the Open status, and document processing can continue. If the document is rejected, it is assigned the Rejected status, and you cannot continue processing the document. You can edit the document after you select the Hold check box on the corresponding form. Budget Validation for Requests If your organization allocates budgets for valuable internal purchases, you can configure budget validation for requests to prevent cost overruns of requested goods and services. An employee who is creating a request can see whether the cost of the items included in the request is below the budget. If the cost exceeds the budget, the employee can edit the list of items in the request. Before you set up this validation, you should make sure that the budgets have been created and released in the system on the ([~/?ScreenId=GL302010|GL302010]) Budgets (GL302010) form. The setup of budget validation for requests includes the following tasks: Defining the way the system will calculate the costs of items included in a request: On the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form, in the Budget Ledger box of the General Settings tab, you select the budget ledger that the system will use for verification. You can also specify the time period over which the system will aggregate amounts from all requests created. In the Budget Calculation box, you select one of the following options: YTD Values : Calculates the total cost of requests created from the beginning of the financial year to the end of the current financial period PTD Values : Calculates the total cost of requests created from the beginning of the financial period Annual : Calculates the total cost of requests created for the current calendar year Turning on budget validation in the settings of each needed request class: On the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ201000|RQ201000]) Request Classes (RQ201000) form, you turn on budget validation by selecting the appropriate option in the Budget Validation box of the GL Accounts tab. (The default setting is None .) If you select Warning , a user will be able to save a request of this class even if the requested amount exceeds the budgeted amount, but the system will display a warning. If you select Error , a user will not be able to save a request of this class with an amount that exceeds the budgeted amount, and the system will display an error message. Processing and Selection of Bids The bidding process entails sending requests for proposals to vendors and choosing the vendor that best meets your company's needs. The Purchase Requisitions module of Acumatica ERP supports and streamlines the bidding process, helping you to reduce purchase expenses. You can manually assign a vendor to the requisition or select the vendor as a result of the bidding process. In this topic, you will read about how to process and select bids. Bid Processing You begin the processing of vendors' bids for a particular requisition when you receive responses (that is, bids) from vendors. The processing involves the following steps: You enter responses into the system by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) Bidding Responses (RQ303000) form. You select the best bids in any of the following ways: By using the automatic algorithm of selecting the best bids. This algorithm uses information about vendor's prices, minimal quantities, and bid quantities of the requested items. For more details, see Automatic Selection of Bids Automatic Selection of Bids. By analyzing responses and selecting vendors manually. For details, see Manual Selection of Bids Manual Selection of Bids. Automatic Selection of Bids You process the bids for a particular requisition by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding (RQ503000) form. To run automatic bidding, you click Update Result on the form toolbar. The system selects a vendor or multiple vendors for each item automatically based on the offered price (bid unit cost) and the quantity limitations (bid quantity), if any, from vendor responses. You can view bidding results and correct them if you are not satisfied with the automatically selected vendors. If any vendor response has changed or been withdrawn after the system selected vendors for a requisition, you enter new responses on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) Bidding Responses (RQ303000) form. Then you go back to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding form, click Clear Result on the form toolbar to clear the selected vendors for all lines of a requisition, and click Update Result again. After you have analyzed and corrected the bidding results, you accept the results by clicking Complete Bidding on the toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding form. The system assigns the selected vendor or vendors to the requisition. Manual Selection of Bids When selecting the best bids, you may want to analyze the bidding responses and select the bids manually. You may want to take into account not only the vendor offering the lowest price but also any of the following: The number of days needed to deliver the order The carrier used by a vendor The shipping terms used by a vendor Special offers from a vendor You can select a vendor with a better bid by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) form as follows: You click the vendor line in the Bidding Vendors table on the Bidding tab and click Choose Vendor on the table toolbar. User Roles for Bid Processing To avoid fraud in selecting bids, you can control which employees can view bidding responses and results. If you want particular users to only enter bidding results, you create a user role that has access to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) Bidding Responses (RQ303000) form and does not have access to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding (RQ503000) and ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) forms and assign this role to the users. For users who are selecting the best bids you create a user role with access to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding and ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions forms and without access to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) Bidding Responses (RQ303000) form and assign this role to the users. For more information, see User Roles: General Information. ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000])

To Set Up Approval of Requests and Requisitions For many businesses, approval of requests and requisitions is essential. In Acumatica ERP, you can set up approval for requests only, requisitions only, or for both types of documents. You can set up approval of requests and requisitions by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form. Before You Proceed Before you proceed with enabling approval, make sure the following steps are completed: Make sure that the Approval Workflow check box is selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. Make sure that needed approval maps and notification templates (if needed) have been configured as described in Managing Assignment and Approval Maps. The approval map defines the employees designated for approving documents and the conditions that documents must match to be assigned for approval; the template of the notification email will be used by the system for notifying approvers about the documents pending their approval. You need to configure both the approval map and the notification template before you start to set up the approval process on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences form. To Set Up Approval for Requests Open the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form. On the General Settings tab of this form, in the Request Settings section, select the Require Approval check box. On the Approval tab, If you have configured an approval map for requests, add it as follows: Click Add Row . In the Type column, select Request . In the Approval Map column, select the approval map to be used for requests. If no map is selected for requests, all new requests will be automatically approved. In the Pending Approval Notification column, select the email template you created for generating emails about requests that are pending approval. If multiple parallel approvals are required for requests, repeat Step 3 for each of the approval maps. Click Save on the form toolbar. To Set Up Approval for Requisitions Open the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form. On the General Settings tab of this form, in the Requisition Settings section, select the Require Approval check box. On the Approval tab, if you have configured an approval map for requisitions, add it as follows: Click Add Row . In the Type column, select Requisition . In the Approval Map column, select the approval map to be used for requisitions. If no map is selected for requisitions, all new requisitions will be automatically approved. In the Pending Approval Notification column, select the email template you created for generating emails about requisitions that are pending approval. If multiple parallel approvals are required for requisitions, repeat Step 3 for each of the approval maps. Click Save on the form toolbar.
